text: The order_items table stores every line-item that makes up an order, acting as the detailed “shopping cart” snapshot at the moment of purchase. Each row is uniquely identified by order_item_id and is tightly linked to the parent orders record via order_id and to the master products catalog through product_id. A boolean-style flag is_primary_item lets analysts quickly isolate the main product in bundles or multi-item carts. Cost and revenue are captured in parallel currencies—USD and INR—so finance can track both top-line price_usd/price_inr and bottom-line cost-of-goods-sold (cogs_usd/cogs_inr) for margin analysis. The created_at timestamp marks when the line item was inserted, which is usually within seconds of checkout. In short, this table answers “What exactly did the customer buy, what did we charge, and what did it cost us?”

The orders table is the canonical header for every successful purchase, representing the moment a shopping session converts into revenue. Its primary key, order_id, ties together the customer (user_id), their web session (session_id), and the single product flagged as the primary purchase driver (primary_product_id). The row also caches the total number of distinct items purchased and the full order value and cost in both USD and INR, eliminating the need to recalculate from line items for quick reporting. A created_at timestamp records the exact checkout moment, enabling cohort and daily revenue analytics. Orders therefore serve as the central aggregation point—linking user behavior captured in sessions to the granular line items and ultimately to refunds if any are issued.

The pageviews table is the raw clickstream log: every URL load tagged with the visitor’s session_id and the precise created_at timestamp. Each pageview_id is a unique event that can be joined back to sessions to understand navigation paths, product page popularity, funnel drop-offs, and campaign attribution. The pageview_url field holds the full relative path, allowing analysts to slice by landing pages, product SKUs, or checkout steps. Because it sits between sessions and orders, this table is the backbone for conversion-rate and attribution modeling—answering “Where did users go, and how did that journey end?”

The products table is the master catalog, one row per sellable SKU. product_id is the immutable key referenced by orders, order_items, and refunds. The created_at timestamp marks when the SKU was first loaded into the system, while product_name provides human-readable identification. Because pricing and cost sit in the transactional tables, this table stays thin—its main purpose is to translate product_id into something analysts and marketers can recognize when building reports or recommendation engines.

The refunds table captures every return or partial refund after purchase. It links back to both the specific order_item_id (what was returned) and the parent order_id (which customer and session originated the sale). refund_amount_usd and refund_amount_inr store the actual cash reversed to the customer, enabling net-revenue calculations. The created_at timestamp marks when the refund was processed, allowing finance to track daily cash outflows and support to audit refund velocity and reasons.

The sessions table is the top-level container for a user’s visit, whether they buy or not. session_id is the durable key shared across pageviews and, if it ends in a sale, the orders table. Core attribution dimensions—utm_source, utm_campaign, utm_content—are captured at session start, letting marketing trace revenue back to ad spend. Additional context like device_type and the referring HTTP header (http_referer) supports UX and SEO analytics. A boolean is_repeat_session flag differentiates new vs. returning visitors, while user_id allows stitching multiple sessions into a customer journey. Created_at is the session start time, anchoring the entire clickstream timeline.
